messages: 3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (01:48): putting type="text/javascript" in <script ‚Ä¶> is redundant and unnecessary, correct?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:49): Yes, since everyone defaults to JS
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (01:53): it's very nice when writing tutorials to be able to drop all the BS extra voodoo characters normally used
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:56): (<style type> is the same - it's really not useful to explicitly tell the browser that you want the same stylesheet language as 100% of other web pages)
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (01:57): ah, hadn't thought of that one.  thanks :)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:59): http://www.centralfloridaregional.com/ - that has a strangely excessive use of 'xmlns:msxsl="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:xslt" xmlns:ehcCopyright="http://www.ehc.com" xmlns:ehcOpenCube="http://www.ehc.com" xmlns:ehcSiteSearch="http://www.ehc.com"'
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:01): does that do anything at all?
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:01): maybe it helps their back-end tools?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:03): The output isn't trying to be XML, so I expect they're not intending to read it back in and process it, and it looks like it's just leaking out of whatever backend tools they're using
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:04): so I think it doesn't help anything, and it just looks really ugly :-)
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:06): so should type="text/css" be dropped from <link rel="stylesheet" ‚Ä¶> as well then?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:10): I don't see any value in keeping it, unless there's some reason that I'm missing
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:11): 3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653: My font doesn't have that glyph :-p
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:11): the unicode up arrow? :)
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:12): sorry, i'll stick to --^ in the future ;)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): right. <video>.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): 3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653: my next target in dealing with spec feedback.
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:13): ah, okay.  so nothing to do with whether type="text/css" is needed in <link rel="stylesheet" ‚Ä¶> then :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): no, sorry, was just talking to myself :-)
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:13): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: how many outstanding emails do you have? :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): not counting the issues on the htmlwg wiki, http://www.whatwg.org/issues/data.csv
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): (third column)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): i'm aiming to reach 3500 by dec31, though i'm not sure if i'll shoot past that target or not
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): i don't know how many i can do per quarter yet
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:15): How predictable is the rate of new issues?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): still, the trend is downwards currently
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: hard to say
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: but that number is (new issues)-(completed issues)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): so right now the rate of replying is > the rate of new issues
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): on average
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): hm. i should get an LED display that shows this number and hang it in my cube
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:22): sounds depressing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): why?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:24): having this much feedback is awesome
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:24): it means people care about the spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:24): and means the spec stands a chance of being good

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:25): You could get a big bucket and fill it with 3723 small items of food, and refill/eat as necessary to keep the number in sync with the number of outstanding issues, to provide a visual indication of progress
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): mmm
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): i don't think that would work well with the kind of food i eat
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (02:29): you need something very small, that never goes bad
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:29): peanuts
